Sure, I can break down the suggested agenda into a moderator's matrix table. Here is one example:

| Agenda Item | Moderator | Time Allotted |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Icebreaker | Moderator from either team | 10 minutes |
| Review of last year's project | Moderator from the donor organization | 30 minutes |
| Setting expectations for the new year | Moderator from the NGO | 60 minutes |
| Communication and collaboration | Moderator from the donor organization | 60 minutes |
| Conflict resolution | Moderator from the NGO | 30 minutes |
| Action planning | Moderator from either team | 20 minutes |
| Wrap-up | Moderator from the donor organization | 10 minutes |

For each agenda item, the moderator responsible for leading the discussion is identified, along with the time allotted for the session. The moderators could be chosen based on their expertise or experience related to the specific agenda item. For example, the moderator from the NGO could lead the discussion on setting expectations for the new year since they have more direct experience with the local context. The goal is to have a balanced approach where both teams have an opportunity to lead discussions and share their perspectives.

Sure, here is an updated version of the moderator's matrix table with additional columns for the goals of each session and what to prepare:

| Agenda Item | Moderator | Time Allotted | Goal of Session | What to Prepare |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Icebreaker | Moderator from either team | 10 minutes | Set a positive tone and ease any tension | None |
| Review of last year's project | Moderator from the donor organization | 30 minutes | Review successes and challenges of the previous year's project | Data and insights from the previous year's project |
| Setting expectations for the new year | Moderator from the NGO | 60 minutes | Align both teams' expectations and discuss potential challenges | Goals and objectives for the upcoming year's project |
| Communication and collaboration | Moderator from the donor organization | 60 minutes | Improve communication and collaboration between the teams | Communication preferences, collaboration methods and tools |
| Conflict resolution | Moderator from the NGO | 30 minutes | Develop a plan for constructive conflict resolution | Potential conflicts and suggested methods for resolution |
| Action planning | Moderator from either team | 20 minutes | Agree on specific actions for improving the relationship and setting the stage for the new year project | Action items for each team and the responsible individuals or teams |
| Wrap-up | Moderator from the donor organization | 10 minutes | Summarize the key discussion points and action items | Feedback on the workshop's effectiveness and suggestions for future improvements |

The updated table includes columns for the goal of each session and what to prepare for each session. This information can help the moderators and participants prepare for each session and stay focused on the goals of the workshop. For example, for the session on setting expectations for the new year, the goal is to align both teams' expectations and discuss potential challenges. To prepare for this session, both teams should come with their goals and objectives for the upcoming year's project. This will help to facilitate a more productive and focused discussion.
